Can you elaborate on the process of artistic creation? How are artists akin to translators who discern signals from their surroundings?

Yes, an instance that lately has been prominent in my mind is the collaboration I had with Neil Young on our latest album, “World Record.” What's fascinating about this was the manner in which it sparked from simple, ignored acts - Neil was on his daily hiking rout in Colorado and he observed that he was constantly whistling. Even though he rarely whistles and isn't particularly adept at it, he was struck by this behavior.
Can you explain more about how inspiration for art can manifest in everyday occurrences? For instance, how did Neil Young's hiking and whistling habit influence his music?

It's quite interesting, really. To provide a concrete example from my recent experience, Neil Young and I came up with our fresh album,“World Record”. The birthplace of this creativity was when Neil was engulfed in his daily routine of hiking in Colorado. To his surprise, he noticed himself whistling quite frequently, even though he is not typically a regular or skilled whistler. The whole situation propelled him into the creation of our new album.

Let’s talk about that philosophy. And I want to start with something you say very early in the book that seems very important to me, which is you frame artists, and, really, you frame all of us, as translators, as picking up signals from the world around them, that many hear but ignore or maybe many never even hear.

The first example that comes to mind is recent. I just made a new album with Neil Young. And it’s called “World Record.” And the way that that came about was he was hiking in Colorado on a daily basis. And he noticed that he was whistling. And he doesn’t whistle much, and he doesn’t whistle well, but he noticed that he was whistling.

You've hinted at the concept of rituals and their significance. We've shared thoughts on meditation, yet it would be interesting to learn about more unconventional or lesser-known rituals that people may misconstrue as mere habits. Could you share experiences from your interaction with artists or teachers that revealed their unique rituals for maintaining awareness?

Absolutely. The one that immediately strikes me might not necessarily encompass awareness, but it's heavily about connection. For instance, just before we started our conversation, I actually performed a personal ritual, wherein I conceptualized an image of my higher self, visualizing it hovering above me.

We have been discussing various rituals and while meditations have been widely understood, there are some rituals which people consider as just living or habit, due to lack of understanding. From your work with artists, have you observed any such rituals, which we may not recognize as such, but are significant in nurturing awareness?

Oh yes. One significant practice that is not strictly about awareness but is more about building connections stands out. Before starting our conversation, I performed a ritual that may seem like a habit to others, where I mentally connected with my higher self, visualizing it above my physical being.

You say that awareness is a practice maintained by rituals. We’ve talked a bit about meditation here. But tell me about some of the other rituals you’ve seen and particularly things that maybe somebody from the outside wouldn’t realize is a ritual. What in the artists you’ve worked with or the people you’ve learned from have you seen as a ritual of awareness that might to someone else simply look like living or habit or routine?

The first one that comes to mind is not one of awareness. It’s of connection. And it was right before we started this together. I did a ritual for us where I imagined my higher self — I envisioned my higher self floating above me.

Could you explain how you perceive the filter and the vessel in your philosophy?

In my understanding, the vessel is a metaphor for us; it is the repository of every experience and observation we've gathered during our lifetime. Sometimes, we intentionally collect these, and other times, they find their way into our vessel unprompted.
What do you mean by the vessel storing both intentional and unintentional knowledge?

By this, I mean that the vessel, symbolizing us, not only contains things that we consciously absorb and remember but also retains information and experiences that have subtly influenced us without our realization.
Tell me about what you call the vessel and the filter.
The vessel is the part of us that holds everything that we’ve seen over the course of our lives. And the vessel contains things that we collect and things that get in there without us knowing.
